title: John Ray Walk Route

images.title: Robin Webster / Footpath junction on the John Ray walk
images.caption: Footpath junction on the John Ray walk. John Ray is sometimes called the father of British natural history. He was born at nearby Black Notley in 1627.

images.title: Glyn Baker / Cowslips on John Ray Walk
images.caption: Cowslips and waymarker post on the trail near Silver End. It was John Ray who coined the trems pollen and petal.

images.title: Robert Edwards / John Ray Cottage, Black Notley, Essex
images.caption: John Ray Cottage, Black Notley, Essex. This was the home of the famous botanist, John Ray, who was born here on 29th November 1627.

images.title: Tim Heaton / River Witham entering South Witham
images.caption: River Witham entering South Witham

images.caption: Black Notley Hall

images.caption: Footpath through the fields near White Notley.

images.title: Glyn Baker / Footpath & Rivenhall Thicks
images.caption: Footpath & Rivenhall Thicks. This is the footpath from Silver End to Whitham the wood in the background is Rivenhall Thicks

images.title: Glyn Baker / Footpath from Whitehead Farm
images.caption: This is the footpath from Whitehead Farm to Temple Lane

description: Travel along the John Ray Walk from Braintree to Witham on this lovely walk through Essex. You will pass through the delightful countryside of the Brain Valley, the birthplace and home of John Ray. Heralded as the father of English natural history he had a supreme understanding of the natural world. One of Ray's greatest achievements was to lay the foundations for the classification of all living things. At the end of the route you could try the Witham River Walk which continues south along the River Brain to the Whetmead Nature Reserve.
